awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of Misinformation on the Covid-19 Response in Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
Though a small body of prior research on health misinformation exists, there is a pressing need to gain a better understanding of how to detect, monitor and understand misinformation and its impact on population health during emergencies. This qualitative study investigates the role of misinformation in Alaska’s response to Covid-19 using systems mapping and data gathered from semi-structured interviews. The project takes a One Health approach, documenting perspectives of public health officials and healthcare providers on misinformation. 

The field of infodemiology investigates the determinants and distribution of health misinformation and its effects on public and individual health. This research investigates qualitative impacts of misinformation on individuals, private entities, and public agencies in Alaska using the OH-SMART (One Health Systems Mapping and Analysis Resource Toolkit) framework. Methods include semi-structured interviews and snowball sampling of public health personnel and healthcare providers. Project results will be disseminated via a dissertation, peer-reviewed journal articles, and conference presentations. The co-PI also plans to engage the public via social media and to develop a digital dashboard.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report


Describe the project outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merit and broader of impacts of your work as defined in the NSF merit review criteria.


Funding from this DDRIG supported 14 months of work towards the third and most substantial research aim within the student’s (co-PI) dissertation. This qualitative study aims to investigate the role of misinformation in hindering one Arctic region’s response to Covid-19 using a systems mapping method from the One Health field and rich data gathered from semi-structured interviews. The primary objective is to investigate the impact of misinformation on public health entities' ability to respond effectively.


The study identified three cross-cutting themes centered around the impact of misinformation on the COVID-19 response in Alaska: misinformation management, impacts of misinformation and lessons learned. Each of these themes contains sub-categories and specific examples of how misinformation and the broader infodemic created barriers and challenges for various response sectors. This is the first qualitative study producing direct insights into the impacts of misinformation and lessons learned from COVID-19 responders in Alaska. 



Briefly summarize the outcomes of your award (200 - 800 words) covering the entire life of the award.


The major outcomes of the award include:

  • Completion of 21 semi-structured interviews and data analysis (mixed thematic analysis) for this study. The student completed these interviews over Zoom over a three month period. This concluded the data collection portion of the research. The student then completed the data analysis using NVivo with a mixed thematic analysis approach.

  • Manuscript generation for the third research aim of the dissertation. Following the data collection and analysis, a manuscript was developed with the assistance of the student’s doctoral committee. 

  • Acceptance of an abstract to the foremost Arctic health conference, the 18th International Congress of Circumpolar Health. The student submitted their manuscript abstract to the ICCH council, where it was accepted as a presentation. Pending funding to travel to the event, the student will present their work at this conference, which is one of the major conferences for the public health field in the Arctic region. This conference will take place in November and will be a great opportunity for the student to share the work funded by this grant with fellow scientists. 

  • Dissertation completion and publication to ProQuest. The dissertation was approved by the necessary individuals in August and was accepted by the graduate school. The dissertation was then sent to ProQuest and published as a doctoral dissertation. 

  • Graduation from the PhD program. The student was then able to graduate from the Interdisciplinary PhD program with a focus in epidemiology from the University of Alaska Fairbanks.This research would not have been possible without the funding from the NSF DDRIG Arctic Social Sciences program.


 


Last Modified: 09/17/2024
Modified by: Emily K Maxwell
